page.title: 18Local History of Ringland
page.content: Elderly residents remember many more{shops}making them almost self- sufficient. Some went to Norwich only twice a year to buy winter and summer clothes. They went by{horse & cart which crossed through the river as there was only a footbridge until the 1920s. The{school}had at least 60 pupils and 3 teachers financed by the {Le Neve}trust and the villagers. The schoolmaster charged 4d. per week. The{church}tower dates from the 13th century, the stained glass from the 14th and 15th centuries and the hammer beam roof from the 15th. The Le Neve arms appear on some memorials. In 1970 it was in danger of closing, but local people made concerted efforts to restore it and since then it is looked after and regular services held. The Rev. Hewetson is vicar for this parish as well as for Taverham.{(Mrs J. Sims)
